Posts.Content: My reaction in the early stages of ADT Zoladex was the reverse, I found I would have 3-4 days of diarrhoea and then be okay for 3-4 weeks, this would just repeat for some 18 months before I seem to have got used to the treatment. Good luck

Posts.Title: Constipation from hormone therapy?

Posts.Content: Chris, Absolutely to the short term memory loss, I have been on Hormone treatment for just over 2 1/2 years now and my short term memory is hopeless. I have no problem with past history, infact I have very good memories of things 50+ years ago. My wife can ring me and ask me to pick up a 1 litre of milk on the way home from work, there is a ninety percent chance I will come home without the milk.
Posts.Signature: Dx PC July 2010 aged 66. Gleason 9, PSA 254 at Dx, Zoladex. PSA April 2011 3.2 March 2014 24 Apr '14 18 Xtandi May '14 2.4 June '14 0.99 June 0.79 Sept 0.46 Oct 0.24 Dec 0.20 Feel well and generally in good health
Posts.Title: memory

Posts.Content: My PSA was 200 when diagnosed early July 2010, rose to 254 in 7 days. I had 11/12 positive biopsy cores Gleason 50% 9 and 42% Gleason 8, CT and Bone scans confirmed metastized PC to base of my spine, pelvis and shoulder. Also to my lymph nodes. Have been on Casodex for first 30 days and have had 3 monthly injections of Zolodex. My PSA dropped to 3.2 by April 2011, then slowly started to rise again,by 3rd December 2011 was up to 5.3, it was obvious that my treatment had failed and I had become castrate resistant. I decided to be proactive and try to join a clinical trial, I applied for the Prevail trial of MDV3100, after my medicals etc I was accepted. Commenced the trial on 23/12/2011. My PSA continued to rise October 2012 was 8.1, however, my scans in May 2012 showed that the metastized PC in my bones was now classed as immeasurable, however, the evidence of the PC in the bones was still evident.For me this is a miracle. I was 66 when diagnosed. I would seek another opinion, investigate a clinical trial. I also feel April is a long time off for more blood work, in my early days after diagnosis was having monthly PSA tests until the PSA had dropped dramatically then reverted to bimonthly, but when I started the trial I was back to monthly PSA, December 2012 was my last montly I have now been put on 3 monthly (March 2013). You need to read more about PC, search the internet there are some wonderfull rescources which I am sure you will find helpfull. There is another forum "Healing Well" which is also very good. All the best.

Posts.Title: Husband just diagnosed with Advanced PC

Posts.Content: I have been on Xtandi since April 2014, my PSA was 18 then, my PSA dropped to 2.4 in a month and by late December was 0.2. I have been on Zoladex since August 2010,and suffer from all of the usual ADT SE, However, as far as I am concerned the only difference is a bit more fatigue and hot flushes. It maybe effecting my blood pressure because I have had to modify my BP medication. My BP is now a lot lower, Xtandi is supposed to increase BP. We are all different and you may have different SE to me and may not get as high a drop in PSA, incidentally my current PSA is lower than what it was 15 years ago ! The big question is how long this will remain low.

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: Guys, I am new here and need some advice. I have metastized PC, which was diagnosed in July 2010. PSA 254, now 5.1, Gleason score 4+4 with some 4+5, treatment has been Cosudex for 1 month and then Zoladex 3 monthly since. I have no pain or sympthoms other than urinary frequency and of course the total package of SE from the HT. My PSA got down to 3.2 in April 2011, since April my PSA see sawed up and down to 6.1 in June 2012, I joined the Prevail clinical trial of MDV3100 in December 2011. My PSA still continued to see saw but finally peaked at 6.1 in June and then dropped in July to 5.9 in August to 5.1, maybe the MDV is starting to influence my PC's PSA number. My urinary frequency has been progressively getting worse, I am now voiding 12-14 times per day. This includes 3-4-5 times getting out of bed at night. I am on Flomaxtra, but this doesn't seem to be making a difference. My question is, the pros and cons of a standard TURP, greenlight laser or holmium laser . Which should give me the best outcome, shortest time in hospital, shortest time with catheter, and least likely to make my PC worse ? I understand the holmium laser gives the opportunity for pathology testing of the removed bits of the prostate. But if the procedure will likely effect my PC I may be better to put up with the frequency. Thanks
Posts.Title: Turp

Posts.Content: I have had the Turp. All went well, very little pain and only had the catheter in for 48 hours. I am still bleeding a little but it is not a concern, I need to wear a light pad because I am still dripping a little. My flow has improved drammatically and I am now only getting up once or twice a night, whereas prior I was getting up 5-6 times a night. The only downside is the urgency, when I feel the need to void I have to make tracks to the toilet because there is no holding back. I hope this will improve with time.

Posts.Title: Turp

Posts.Content: As I posted earlier, normally you would be still on Zoladex or Lupron and yes ED is the standard SE of this. I have ED and the tablets don't work and I am not game to try the injections. Just the thought is enough to send shivers down my spine. I haven't read anything on the sexual side effects of MDV but as you say it is probably very high.
Posts.Signature: Dx PC July 2010 aged 66. Gleason 9, PSA 254 at Dx, Zoladex. PSA April 2011 3.2 March 2014 24 Apr '14 18 Xtandi May '14 2.4 June '14 0.99 June 0.79 Sept 0.46 Oct 0.24 Dec 0.20 Feel well and generally in good health
Posts.Title: MDV3100 side effects

Posts.Content: I am also sure you would be still on Zoladex or Lupron. All the MDV trials have been with these as standard care. As replicant stated you would have ED already and there would be no change. I am still on Zoladex and MDV and have ED. I think there is a Stage I trial starting soon for MDV as a first line medication, but the results and use will be a long time off yet. I have advanced PC which has metastized and the MDV is having fantastic results. I am in the Prevail trial. Best wishes
Posts.Title: MDV3100 side effects

Posts.Content: Sequoiaranger, I have been on MDV3100 since December 2011. My PSA started in July 2010 at 254 by 1/4/2011 had come down to 3.2, then progressively increased until May 2012. Bone and CT scans in July 2010 confirmed metastized PC to lymph nodes and bones. Scans in December 2011 showed increased PC in my bones. MDV3100 didn't seem to do much until June 2012 when scans still showed evidence of PC but were classified as unmeasurable. This is a miracle. My PSA has stablised at around 6.4, I am very fortunate that so far I have no bone pain. The SE from MDV are very manageable, Hot flushes, headaches and diarrhoea. In my case these come and go. The hot flushes I get from Zoladex anyway, the headaches and diarrhoea are now getting less frequent, in fact in September were virtually non existent. My PSA didn't follow the trend shown in the Affirm trial where 80% of the guys showed a dramatic drop in their PSA, naturally I fell into the 20% where there was no reduction in PSA. Zoladex basically only worked for about 8 months for me before my PSA was on the increase.
Posts.Title: MDV3100 side effects

Posts.Content: Sequolaranger, I was Dx with PC in July 2010 aged 66, my PSA was 254, my biopsy result was Gleason 9 in 50%, Gleason 8 from 40% and 1 negative from 12 cores. CT and Bone scans confirmed Metastized PC in my bones and lymph nodes. I started Cosudex late July 2010 for 4 weeks and had my first Zoladex injection mid August 2010. I am still on quarterly injections, my next is in November. I am very fortunate I am not in any pain, the only symptom I have is urinary frequency (and this is not necessarily a symptom of PC). The only indicator I have of PC is my PSA, Biopsy results and the evidence of my scans. About the same time I found I needed cardiac surgery requiring a double bypass and a new valve. The rehabilitation for the heart surgery and subsequent doctors visits, tests and physical rehabilitation in the hospital gym kept me fairly busy and I didn’t have time to worry too much about my PC, even my cardiologist said to me your heart is more important it could kill you, your PC won’t ! My PSA started to come down and the urologist was happy with the results, I still was very na√Øve and knew almost nothing about PC and the SE of the treatment. In hindsight I am very disappointed with the quality and amount of the information I was given at the time of diagnosis. I was given no information about the SE, particularly the sexual side. I remember rather casually being asked, have you finished your family? At the time I didn’t put any emphasis on this because I was 66, married 39 years and have 3 daughters in their 30’s and soon to become a grandfather for the first time I also was in shock and it was all a blurr, I didn’t know what questions to ask so you just go along with the diagnosis and recommended treatment. I do remember being told because of the stage of my PC it was a waste of time removing my prostate. Also my PSA “should” come down to well under 1 and he would be seeing me for many years. Again in hindsight very sugar coated. After about 8 months my PSA was down to 3.2 (April 2011) this was as low as it got. After April my PSA started to rise again and over the next 6 months my PSA almost doubled. After getting over my cardiac surgery I thought more about my PC and decided to do some research and find out more about this cancer. I was shocked to see the information and the information I wasn’t told about. I also discovered information about clinical trials and decided that I would join a trial in the future when my cancer started to take off. Little did I know that this was going to be sooner than later. I had follow up scans in November 2011 which confirmed the cancer in my bones had progressed. I had read about MDV3100 and was impressed with the results of the Affirm trial and decided that the Prevail trial sounded like the suitable trial for me, that is if I was selected. I had my physical, blood tests, and medical reports assessed and I was told I qualified. I think there were less than 10 positions available at my hospital. I took all of 10 seconds to accept the offer. I started the trial mid December 2011, I was fully aware and worried that I would get the placebo but was prepared to take the risk. My PSA continued to go up and down over the next 5 months, my bi-monthly scans indicated no change from the starting scans. I was getting depressed and worried that I had made the wrong choice and had scored the Placebo. However, come June 2012 the scans still showed evidence of my PC but the cancer was now classified as unmeasurable. This is a miracle; my August scans showed no change from June and again was classified as unmeasurable. My October 2012 PSA is now back to about the same as in October 2011. My PSA hasn’t showed the dramatic drop in level that about 80% of the Affirm Trial participants enjoyed. I obviously fall into the other 20%. The PSA number is difficult, your life hinges around this number, if it is up you are down if the number is down you are up. (bit like an umbrella in wet weather !) From the SE side of things on Zoladex, I suffered from hot flushes, fatigue, ED, penile shrinkage,depression, short term memory loss, weight gain, loss of stamina, loss of muscle strength, got irritable, am very emotional, easily upset over trivial times. All this has put a huge strain on our marriage and I find that my wife really doesn’t understand what I am going through emotionally. On the sexual side of things I really didn’t notice any real change until after my cardiac recovery, because I was forbidden to have intercourse until November/December 2010 because of the breast bone still knitting together. I did notice that I wasn’t waking up with my usual morning erection but really didn’t put 2 and 2 together. After I started the MDV3100 trial, the only changes to the existing SE was a little more fatigue, headaches and diarrhoea. Also an increase in my blood pressure. I am still receiving quarterly Zoladex injections, I still work full time and work 10+ hours per day 5 days a week. Some of the fatigue can be attributed to my working hours. But prior to my PC Dx I really didn’t suffer from much fatigue. I am project manager responsible for the maintenance of the plant and equipment, building maintenance, equipment purchasing and factory expansion, so I have a very active working day. The headaches and diarrhoea are getting less frequent, infact I had no diarrhoea in September. My body must be getting accustomed to the drug. The SE as far as I am concerned are easily manageable and there is no way I could class the fatigue as extreme. I still have the other SE from the Zoladex but I suppose I am slowly getting a little more tolerant of these. My BP has been another story, my Doctors have spent from January 2012 until now tweaking my BP medication in an attempt to keep my BP down. I have been changing, reducing, increasing or adding BP medication to lower and keep my BP down. The last 2-3 weeks has been a lot better and my BP seems to be much lower and an acceptable level. I have also joined a gym in an attempt to increase my muscle strength and stamina in my legs, I have been finding even though I am active the (Zoladex) treatment is effecting my stamina. I am on the standard dose of MDV3100 (I can’t get used to calling it by it’s new fangled name) this is 4 x 40mg once a day, I take mine every evening around 6.30pm. The initial trials seemed to indicate that 4x40mg was the optimum dose, it doesn’t need to be taken before or after food, just around the same time each day. I am also allowed to take my other medication at the same time. I don’t notice any effects of the MDV after taking it. The only thing is the capsules are huge and they need to be swallowed one at a time, my other medication I take a handful in one gulp ! I hope this gives you some insight into my experience with my Dx, PC and the trial. It is still early days, but so far the drug seems to have put a slow down to the advancement of my PC. For this I am eternally grateful and am very thankful to the developers of MDV3100.

on this because I was 66  married 39 years and have

Posts.Title: MDV3100 side effects

Posts.Content: TURP is a transurethral resection of the prostate, just the full name sounds painfull ! Or in laymans language a "rebore" to relieve the urinary problems of slow flow, hard to start , dribbling at the end and to hopefully empty the bladder to stop urinary frequency.
Posts.Title: Turp

Posts.Content: I am having the Holmium Laser Turp on 29/10/2012. After much research I have decided this is the best option for me. Cystoscopy and urodynamic tests confirmed the necessity , along with many nights of broken sleep because of numerous nightly trips to the bathroom. Hopefully this will fix the problem.
Posts.Signature: Dx PC July 2010 aged 66. Gleason 9, PSA 254 at Dx, Zoladex. PSA April 2011 3.2 March 2014 24 Apr '14 18 Xtandi May '14 2.4 June '14 0.99 June 0.79 Sept 0.46 Oct 0.24 Dec 0.20 Feel well and generally in good health
Posts.Title: Turp

Posts.Content: What the others have said is true, there is no use having a prostatectomy if the cancer has moved on. There is no benefit of doing the operation in an attempt to cure the cancer, all you are going to do is go through a major operation, suffer from incontinence all for nothing, initially the standard treatment is hormone treatment, this can work for a short period or many years. At this stage there doesn't seem to be a way of determining easily what sort of PC you have and the likely timeframe hormones are going to be effective or infact if you require any treatment at all other than active surveilence. The time just depends on the individual cancer, in my case it only worked for about 9 months before my PSA started to rise. Initially my PSA went from 254 to 3.2 over 9 months, it then went up to 8.1 in 18 months. HT for me is still sort of working, it has slowed the cancer down, but I have also joined the Prevail trial of Xtandi which I have been in for some 15 months now, this has also helped shrink the metastised cancer in my bones.
Posts.Signature: Dx PC July 2010 aged 66. Gleason 9, PSA 254 at Dx, Zoladex. PSA April 2011 3.2 March 2014 24 Apr '14 18 Xtandi May '14 2.4 June '14 0.99 June 0.79 Sept 0.46 Oct 0.24 Dec 0.20 Feel well and generally in good health
Posts.Title: Prostatectomy when there is bone involvement?

Posts.Content: I am not sure about the status of Zytiga, but Xtandi is only approved for post chemotherapy. Medivation the company who has developed the drug has just applied for FDA approval for pre-chemotherapy use. I understand that approval will be before September 2014.
